questions.text: What type of amino acid change is seen in sickle cell anaemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sickle cell hemoglobinopathy arises from a point mutation in the beta-globin gene (chromosome 11), leading to the replacement of glutamic acid (hydrophilic) with valine (hydrophobic) at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. This change causes HbS (sickle haemoglobin).
    • The replacement of glutamic acid with valine makes the haemoglobin molecule hydrophobic at the position of mutation.
    • The hydrophobic valine promotes polymerisation of the haemoglobin under low oxygen conditions.
    • This polymerisation leads to the formation of long, rigid fibres, causing sickling of red blood cells (RBCs).
    • The sickled RBCs lose their flexibility and become trapped in small vessels, causing blockages and leading to complications like pain crises, organ damage, and anaemia.
  • Molecular Mechanism:
    • In deoxygenated conditions, the hydrophobic valine in HbS interacts with other HbS molecules, forming fibres.
    • This leads to a significant decrease in the solubility of HbS compared to normal haemoglobin (HbA), which is soluble and does not polymerise.

Explanation of other options:

Glutamic acid to leucine (Option A): The mutation in sickle cell is from glutamic acid to valine, not leucine.

Valine to leucine (Option B): This mutation does not affect haemoglobin in sickle cell anaemia; it would not cause polymerisation.

Valine to glutamic acid (Option D): This mutation would result in normal haemoglobin (HbA), which is soluble and does not polymerise.

questions.text: The following X-ray skull appearance is most commonly seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "hair on end" appearance on a skull X-ray is characteristic of thalassemia major.
  • This radiologic finding occurs due to the widening of the diploic spaces in the skull, which is a result of marrow hyperplasia due to severe anaemia.
  • In thalassemia major, there is ineffective erythropoiesis and compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis (i.e., the bone marrow expands and causes the skull to show this characteristic appearance).
  • The excessive bone marrow expansion results in trabecular bone formation, which gives rise to the "hair on end" pattern.

Explanation of other options:

Thalassemia trait (Option A): This condition is asymptomatic and does not show the "hair on end" skull appearance.

Sickle cell anaemia (Option C): This condition may cause bone infarctions but typically does not produce the "hair on end" appearance on skull X-rays.

Osteopetrosis (Option D): This condition results in increased bone density and bone sclerosis but does not show the "hair on end" skull appearance.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl comes to you for evaluation due to easy fatigability noticed by the parents. Her hemogram is done to look for the Hb level and diagnose anaemia. What shall be the cut-off of Hb for this child, according to WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to the WHO classification, anaemia in children aged 5-11 years is defined as haemoglobin <11.5 g/dL.
  • This Hb threshold is used globally for diagnosing anaemia in pediatric patients in this age group, which includes the 6-year-old child in this scenario. These cut-offs are critical in identifying and managing childhood anaemia, especially in resource-limited settings

WHO Cut-offs for anaemia are as follows

  • 6 months - 5 years: Hb< 11gm/dl.
  • 5 years - 11 years: Hb < 11.5g/dl
  • 12-13 years:Hb <12 g/dl
  • Adult male:Hb < 13g/dl
  • Adult non-pregnant female: Hb < 12g/dl

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate will control bleeding due to deficiency of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cryoprecipitate contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor (vWF), and fibronectin, but not factor IX.
  • Therefore, it is not effective in treating Factor IX deficiency (Haemophilia B). In such cases, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or specific factor IX concentrates are used.

Cryoprecipitate is particularly useful in the following conditions:

  • Hypofibrinogenemia (due to DIC or liver failure)
  • von Willebrand disease (especially types 1 and 2 if specific concentrates are unavailable)
  • Haemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) in emergencies if recombinant factor VIII is unavailable

Explanation of other options:

Hypofibrinogenemia (Option A): Cryoprecipitate is the treatment of choice because it is rich in fibrinogen.

Factor VIII deficiency (Option B): Cryoprecipitate contains factor VIII and can be used in emergencies.

vWF deficiency (Option D): Cryoprecipitate is a source of von Willebrand factor and may be used when specific vWF concentrates are unavailable.

choices.text: Hemarthroses commonly occur in this disorder
Spontaneous recovery within several weeks is expected
Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed
Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with a few petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly, PT and aPTT normal. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This presentation is classic for acute-onset Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).
  • Most cases of ITP in children resolve spontaneously within 1-2 weeks to a few months, particularly when bleeding is not severe. Observation is sufficient for children who are hemodynamically stable and have no mucosal or life-threatening bleeding.

Key clinical pointers:

  • Recent viral illness (2 weeks ago)
  • Sudden onset of petechiae and bruising
  • Severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count <30,000/μL)
  • No splenomegaly
  • Normal coagulation profile

Management of ITP in children

  • Observation is first-line in children with mild bleeding and platelet count >20000-30,000/μL.
  • First-line pharmacologic treatments:
    • Oral prednisolone
    • IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin)
  • Second-line (for persistent/chronic ITP):
    • Rituximab
    • Thrombopoietin receptor agonists
    • Splenectomy (in select chronic cases)

Indications for Platelet Transfusion in ITP:

  • Severe mucosal bleeding
  • Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Before surgery in patients with critically low counts

Indications for Splenectomy:

  • Chronic ITP (>12 months)
  • Refractory to medical therapy
  • Relapses after tapering off steroids or IVIG
  • Age >5 years is preferred for splenectomy due to infection risk in younger children

Explanation of other options:

Hemarthroses commonly occur in this disorder (Option A): Hemarthroses are typical of coagulation disorders like Haemophilia, not ITP.

Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed (Option C): Platelet transfusions are not routinely indicated in ITP unless there is life-threatening bleeding.

Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged (Option D): Coagulation parameters are normal in ITP since it is a platelet destruction disorder, not a coagulation factor deficiency.

questions.text: In Sickle Cell Anaemia, which drug is used to decrease the incidence of painful vaso-occlusive crises?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hydroxyurea is the cornerstone drug for reducing vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) in patients with sickle cell anaemia.

Hypothesis / Mechanism of Action:

  • Hydroxyurea increases fetal haemoglobin (HbF) HbF interferes with haemoglobin S (HbS) polymerisation, which in turn:
  • Reduces sickling of red cells
  • Decreases vaso-occlusion
  • Improves blood flow in the microvasculature
  • Prevents acute chest syndrome, stroke, and painful crises

Dose: 10-15 mg/kg/day (once daily); requires regular monitoring of complete blood counts for myelosuppression.

Explanation of other options:

Methotrexate-Leucovorin (Option B): Used in cancers and autoimmune diseases. No role in managing sickle cell crises.

Eltrombopag (Option C): A thrombopoietin receptor agonist used for ITP and aplastic anaemia, not vaso-occlusion.

Azathioprine (Option D): An immunosuppressive agent used for autoimmune and transplant cases. Not used in sickle cell disease.

choices.text: Elevated methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels
Target cells on the peripheral smear
Hypocellular bone marrow with fatty infiltration

questions.text: A 9-year-old child, born to vegan parents, presents with complaints of fatigue, pallor, and tingling in the feet. On examination, there is glossitis and mild gait disturbance. CBC shows Hb 9.8 g/dL and MCV of 115 fL. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly support the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child presents with features of macrocytic anaemia (MCV >100 fL), neurological symptoms, and a vegan background, all of which point toward vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency impairs DNA synthesis, particularly in rapidly dividing cells like bone marrow precursors, leading to megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Methylmalonic acid and homocysteine accumulate due to impaired conversion processes dependent on B12, and both are elevated in vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • These metabolites are not elevated in folate deficiency, making them specific diagnostic indicators.

Explanation of other options:

Increased serum ferritin (Option B): Suggests iron overload or inflammation, not related to macrocytic anaemia.

Target cells on peripheral smear (Option C): Typically seen in thalassemia or liver disease, not B12 deficiency.

Hypocellular bone marrow with fatty infiltration (Option D): Seen in aplastic anaemia, which presents with pancytopenia, not macrocytosis with neurologic signs.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy whose parents present to your office for a health supervision visit. The boy is at the third percentile for weight and height. He is pale, and his liver is palpable 3 cm below the costal margin. His parents bring with them laboratory results. If not managed appropriately, this patient's disease course is most likely to be complicated by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical and haematological picture is consistent with beta-thalassemia major:

  • Severe anaemia (Hb 5.2 g/dL)
  • Microcytosis (MCV 59 fL)
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis showing absent HbA, markedly elevated HbF (79%), and elevated HbA2 (21%)
  • Hepatomegaly and growth retardation are early clinical signs

Children with β-thalassemia major require chronic blood transfusions, which over time lead to iron overload due to the absence of a physiological mechanism to excrete excess iron. If not managed with iron chelation therapy, complications include:

  • Liver damage (fibrosis, cirrhosis)
  • Cardiac toxicity (arrhythmias, heart failure)
  • Endocrinopathies (hypogonadism, diabetes, hypothyroidism)

Explanation of other options:

Acute chest syndrome (Option A): Seen in sickle cell disease, not thalassemia.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option B): This patient has iron overload, not deficiency, due to repeated transfusions.

Stroke (Option D): A complication in sickle cell disease, not typical in β-thalassemia major.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with fatigue, pallor, and a recent history of easy bruising. She is afebrile. A complete blood count with differential reveals neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated mean corpuscular volume, and her reticulocyte count is low. She is referred to a pediatric haematologist, and a diagnosis of severe aplastic anaemia is confirmed, with a haemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL. What is the first-line therapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the first-line and curative therapy in children and adolescents with severe or very severe aplastic anaemia, if an HLA-matched sibling donor is available.
  • HSCT provides durable marrow recovery and hematologic cure in >80% of appropriately selected patients.
  • This approach is preferred in younger patients (<20 years) with an available matched sibling donor, due to the higher success rate and lower long-term complications.

Explanation of other options:

Blood transfusion (Option A): Supportive but not curative. Repeated transfusions can lead to alloimmunization.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B): Used in febrile neutropenia, but this patient is afebrile. Not a definitive therapy.

Immunosuppressive therapy (Option D): This is the first-line option only when a matched donor is unavailable, particularly in older children or adults.

questions.text: A 1-week-old presents to your office with bruising and coffee ground emesis. She was a term baby who was born at home and is now exclusively breastfed. Her PT is prolonged >100 seconds, and her aPTT is relatively normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This clinical presentation is consistent with early-onset Vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB) in a breastfed neonate who did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis at birth.
  • Vitamin K is essential for γ-carboxylation (activation) of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.
  • Factor VII, having the shortest half-life (~6 hours), is the first to decrease, leading to isolated prolonged PT.
  • aPTT may remain normal initially as factors VIII and IX decline later or are not yet affected.
  • Breastfed neonates are at risk due to low vitamin K in breast milk.
  • Classical VKDB occurs within the first 2-7 days, especially in babies without prophylactic IM vitamin K.
  • Bleeding manifestations include GI bleeding, skin bruises, mucosal bleeds, and intracranial haemorrhage in late VKDB.

Explanation of other options:

Low factor VIII level (Option A): Would prolong aPTT, not PT. Seen in Haemophilia A, which is not neonatal and does not involve GI bleeding.

Low factor V level (Option B): Would prolong both PT and aPTT since it is part of the common pathway.

Factor V Leiden (Option C): A thrombophilic mutation, not associated with bleeding, and especially not in neonates.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought in with complaints of progressive pallor, fatigue, and intermittent episodes of gum bleeding and low-grade fever over 3 weeks. On examination, there is pallor, petechiae, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Blood work shows anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The peripheral smear shows a blast cell with a needle-like inclusion known as an Auer rod, which is pathognomonic for acute myeloid leukaemia (AML).
  • Auer rods are fused lysosomes or primary granules, seen only in myeloid lineage blasts.
  • Clinical presentation of AML in children includes anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia, with symptoms like fatigue, infections, and bleeding.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and fever are also common.

Explanation of other options:

Blast crisis in AML (Option A) is seen in chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) progressing to the acute phase. Not used for de novo AML.

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option B): Shows macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, not blasts or Auer rods.

Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) (Option D): Lymphoblasts do not have Auer rods; diagnosis supported by TdT positivity and absence of cytoplasmic granules.

questions.text: A child is found to have low serum iron, high ferritin and normal total iron binding capacity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child's iron profile, low serum iron, high ferritin, and normal or low TIBC, is typical of anaemia of chronic disease (ACD).
  • In ACD, inflammatory cytokines (especially IL-6) increase hepcidin production, which inhibits iron release from macrophages and decreases intestinal iron absorption.
  • Ferritin, an acute-phase reactant, is increased, while TIBC remains normal or reduced due to suppressed transferrin production.

Iron Profile Patterns in Microcytic Anaemias

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): Shows low serum iron, low ferritin, and high TIBC, not consistent here.

Thalassemia (Option B): Typically has normal iron studies (iron, ferritin, TIBC all normal), and microcytosis disproportionate to anaemia.

Sideroblastic anaemia (Option C): Shows high serum iron, high ferritin, and low/normal TIBC, not low serum iron.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with increased bleeding following a dental extraction. Local hemostatic measures were ineffective. Her PT is normal, and she has no prior personal or family history of haemophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of mucocutaneous bleeding (post-dental extraction), along with normal PT, is highly suggestive of von Willebrand disease (vWD), especially type 1.
  • vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by a quantitative or qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF).
  • vWF is essential for platelet adhesion and also stabilises factor VIII, explaining the associated mild reduction in factor VIII levels in some cases.
  • The Ristocetin cofactor test is the gold standard for assessing vWF function.
  • It measures the ability of vWF to agglutinate platelets in the presence of Ristocetin.
  • It is reduced in all types of vWD, especially in Types 2 and 3, helping to differentiate from platelet disorders.
  • Type 3vWD behaves similarly to that of Haemophilia A.

Explanation of other options:

Factor VIII deficiency (Haemophilia A) (Option B) and Factor IX deficiency (Haemophilia B) (Option C) are both X-linked recessive, thus rare in females. They typically cause deep tissue or joint bleeding, not mucosal bleeding.

Vitamin K deficiency (Option D) causes prolonged PT and aPTT due to reduced levels of factors II, VII, IX, X. It's not consistent with isolated post-extraction bleeding in a child with normal PT.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with easy bruising. There is no suspicion of trauma. He has short stature, microcephaly, hyperpigmented skin lesions, bilateral hypoplastic thumbs, and a family history of blood disorders. Laboratory workup reveals pancytopenia. He is diagnosed with a genetic syndrome and planned for HSCT, but no matched donor is available. Which drug is most likely to be started as initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is suggestive of Fanconi's Anaemia.

  • Fanconi anaemiais an acquired pancytopenia that includes physical manifestations as well.
  • Certain features include hyperpigmentation or hypopigmentation;short stature; absent radii; hypoplastic, absent, bifid, or supernumerary thumbs; foot, hip or leg anomalies; penile or testicular abnormalities (in males); uterine, ovarian, or vaginal malformations (in females); microcephaly; renal malformations; CVS or GIT malformations.
  • Bone marrow failure with pancytopenia usually ensues.
  • Patients with Fanconi anaemiaare at high risk for squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck and acute myelogenous leukaemia.
  • Management of these patients ismultidisciplinary and should involve a haematologist.
  • If an HLA-matched sibling donor is not available, the first-line supportive therapy is androgen administration (e.g., oxymetholone or danazol).
  • Androgens stimulate erythropoiesis and granulopoiesis and may improve blood counts temporarily in FA patients.

Explanation of other options:

G-CSF (Option A) is reserved for severe neutropenia with recurrent infections but does not treat pancytopenia.

Folate (Option B) is essential in megaloblastic anaemia, but not effective in genetic marrow failure syndromes.

Hydroxyurea (Option C) is used in sickle cell anaemia, not in FA.

questions.text:
A newborn female develops jaundice at 12 hours of life. Her total serum bilirubin is 22.4 mg/dL, with an indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin level of 21.2 mg/dL. The mother's blood group is AB+, and the baby's blood group is A+. The direct Coombs test is negative.
Her CBC shows:
WBC: 15,200/mm³
Haemoglobin: 10 g/dL
Hematocrit: 30%
MCV: 98 fL
MCHC: 37 g/dL
Platelets: 2.75 lakh/mm³
What is the next best diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture suggests non-immune hemolytic anaemia, due to the following clues:

  • Early onset jaundice (<24 hours of life)
  • Elevated indirect hyperbilirubinemia (>20 mg/dL is critical)
  • Low haemoglobin (10 g/dL)
  • High MCHC (37 g/dL)- this is a hallmark feature
  • Negative Coombs test rules out Rh/ABO alloimmunization

These findings are highly suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis (HS), a membrane defect hemolytic anaemia inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

The osmotic fragility test is the classical test to screen for HS, as spherocytes are fragile in hypotonic solutions.

Explanation of other options:

G6PD activity (Option A): More likely in boys (X-linked), and bilirubin rise would not typically be this early unless exposed to oxidative stress.

Haemoglobin electrophoresis (Option B): Useful for hemoglobinopathies (e.g., thalassemia, sickle cell), but not acute neonatal jaundice.

UGT1A1 activity (Option C): Relevant in Crigler-Najjar/Gilbert syndrome, which presents later and not with anaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is the most common cause of aplastic crisis in Sickle Cell Anaemia & Hereditary Spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to transient red cell aplasia.
  • In patients with increased red cell turnover, such as those with Sickle Cell Disease or Hereditary Spherocytosis, this temporary suppression of erythropoiesis results in a profound aplastic crisis.
  • Affected children present with sudden pallor, fatigue, and marked reticulocytopenia, often without significant leukopenia or thrombocytopenia.
  • The condition is self-limiting in most immunocompetent individuals but may require transfusion support during crisis.
  • Mnemonic: "Parvo causes Pause" in RBC production.

Explanation of other options:

Salmonella typhi (Option A): Can cause osteomyelitis in SCD but not aplastic crisis.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): Causes invasive infections in SCD but does not lead to red cell aplasia.

Parainfluenza virus 1 (Option D): A respiratory pathogen, not implicated in bone marrow suppression.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The prothrombin G20210A mutation is one of the most common inherited thrombophilias, found in approximately 2-3% of the general population.
  • It leads to increased prothrombin (factor II) levels, which increases the risk for venous thromboembolism due to enhanced thrombin generation.
  • Factor V Leiden is another common inherited cause of thrombophilia, due to a point mutation making factor V resistant to inactivation by activated protein C (APC resistance).
  • This increases thrombotic risk significantly.

Explanation of other options:

Homocysteine deficiency (Option A): Associated with decreased thrombotic risk. Hyperhomocysteinemia increases thrombosis, not deficiency.

Factor V deficiency (Option C): Causes bleeding, not thrombosis.

Nephritic syndrome (Option D): More often associated with hematuria and hypertension than thrombosis.

questions.text: A child suffering from iron deficiency anaemia was started on oral iron therapy. When will the peak reticulocytosis be anticipated after starting iron?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In iron deficiency anaemia, once oral iron therapy is initiated, reticulocytosis begins within 48-72 hours and peaks between days 5-7.
  • This is due to bone marrow erythroid hyperplasia, following the restoration of intracellular iron and improved erythropoiesis.

Timeline of Response to Iron Therapy

  • 12-24 hours: Replacement of intracellular iron enzymes; subjective improvement, such as decreased irritability and increased appetite.
  • 36-48 hours: Initial bone marrow response begins; erythroid hyperplasia becomes evident.
  • 48-72 hours: Onset of reticulocytosis.
  • Peak reticulocytosis: 5-7 days
  • 4-30 days: An Increase in haemoglobin concentration is observed.
  • 1-3 months: Complete repletion of iron stores occurs.

questions.text: Usual indications for an exchange transfusion in a child with sickle cell disease include?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute chest syndrome is a life-threatening complication of sickle cell disease and is a primary indication for exchange transfusion. This therapy rapidly lowers the proportion of sickled haemoglobin (HbS), improves oxygenation, and decreases disease severity.

Indications for exchange transfusion in sickle cell disease include:

  • Acute chest syndrome
  • Stroke (acute CNS event)
  • Priapism
  • Refractory vaso-occlusive crisis (not responding to hydration, analgesia, oxygen)
  • Multiorgan failure
  • High-risk cardiac disease (e.g., cardiomyopathy)
  • Chronic transfusion program to maintain HbS < 30% after prior stroke
  • Acute hepatic sequestration with worsening liver function

Painful vaso-occlusive crisis is typically managed with analgesics, hydration, and oxygen; exchange transfusion is considered only in refractory cases. (Option A is ruled out)

Splenic sequestration crisis is usually treated with simple red cell transfusion, not exchange. (Option B is ruled out)

Dactylitis is a minor VOC (vaso-occlusive crisis) and usually does not warrant exchange transfusion. (Option D is ruled out)

choices.text: If the patient has >2 episodes of epistaxis in 24 hr

questions.text: A 5-year-old was well till 2 days back when he had profuse bleeding from his nose. You suspect him as an ITP initially, but then decide against it. Which of the following will indicate that the diagnosis is NOT ITP and something else?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ITP typically presents as an isolated thrombocytopenia in an otherwise healthy child and may present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis or petechiae.
  • However, the presence of hepatosplenomegaly, generalised lymphadenopathy, or pancytopenia suggests an alternative diagnosis, such as leukaemia, bone marrow infiltration, or other systemic disorders.
  • Hence, hepatosplenomegaly is a red flag sign against ITP and warrants further evaluation for secondary causes.

Explanation of other options:

More than two episodes of epistaxis in 24 hours (Option A): Epistaxis is a common presentation of ITP due to platelet dysfunction. The frequency alone does not rule out ITP.

Haemoglobin level of 12 g/dL (Option B): Normal haemoglobin does not contradict the diagnosis of ITP; anaemia may be absent early or in mild cases.

Platelet count of 15,000/mm³ (Option C): Severe thrombocytopenia is a classic finding in ITP. Counts below 20,000/mm³ are typical and not a contradiction.

Key Takeaways:

  • ITP usually presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding.
  • The presence of hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy is atypical and suggests alternate diagnoses.
  • A full systemic examination is essential before labelling a case as ITP.

questions.text: Desmopressin is relatively contraindicated in which type of Von Willebrand disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Type 2B Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is characterised by gain-of-function mutations in the vWF gene that increase the affinity of vWF for platelet glycoprotein Ib (GPIb).
  • This enhanced binding causes spontaneous aggregation of platelets, leading to their premature clearance from circulation.
  • Administration of desmopressin in these patients can exacerbate thrombocytopenia by further increasing circulating levels of vWF that promote platelet-vWF binding.

Hence, desmopressin is relatively contraindicated in Type 2B vWD.

questions.text: The type of disease having severe thrombocytopenia with decreased vWF and mildly decreased factor 8 levels in blood is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudo-von Willebrand disease (pseudo-vWD), also called platelet-type vWD, occurs due to a gain-of-function mutation in platelet glycoprotein Ib (GPIb). This mutation increases the spontaneous binding of platelets to circulating vWF, mimicking Type 2B vWD.
  • The key clinical and laboratory features include:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Decreased vWF activity
    • Loss of high-molecular-weight multimers
    • Mild decrease in factor VIII levels
  • Although similar to Type 2B vWD, the underlying defect is in the platelet receptor, not the vWF molecule itself. Specific diagnostic tests (e.g., ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation and genetic analysis) are required to distinguish the two conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Type 1 vWD (Option A): Characterised by partial quantitative deficiency of vWF. Thrombocytopenia is not typically present, and factor VIII is usually near normal.

Type 2A vWD (Option B): Caused by qualitative defects in vWF, leading to loss of high-molecular-weight multimers, but not associated with significant thrombocytopenia.

Type 3 vWD (Option C): A severe quantitative deficiency of vWF. It causes very low factor VIII and no detectable vWF, but thrombocytopenia is usually not a prominent feature.

questions.text: A child presented with mucosal bleeds, superficial petechiae and purpurae, but no muscle bleeds or joint bleeds. He was evaluated, and his platelet count was found to be normal. His PT and aPTT were also within normal limits. However, the ristocetin assay was abnormal while there was normal platelet aggregation in response to ADP. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child has a platelet function disorder (normal platelet count + mucocutaneous bleeding).
  • PT and aPTT are normal, which rules out coagulation factor deficiencies. The key differentiator is the abnormal response to ristocetin-this strongly suggests Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Ristocetin Test (Mechanism):

  • Ristocetin is an antibiotic that promotes vWF-dependent platelet agglutination by enabling vWF to bind to platelet glycoprotein Ib (GpIb).
  • In Bernard-Soulier syndrome (GpIb defect), abnormal (absent) aggregation with ristocetin.
  • In vWD (vWF defect), also an abnormal response, but corrected with normal plasma.
  • In Glanzmann thrombasthenia (GpIIb/IIIa defect): normal aggregation with ristocetin, but defective with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine.

Bernard-Soulier Syndrome vs Glanzmann Thrombasthenia

Explanation of other options:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Option A): Platelet count would be decreased in ITP. Since this child has a normal platelet count, ITP is ruled out.

Parahemophilia (Option D) (Factor V deficiency) presents with abnormal PT and/or aPTT, not normal coagulation studies. Also, it causes deep tissue and joint bleeds, not mucocutaneous bleeding.

questions.text: Reduced levels of which clotting factor can produce Haemophilia C?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Factor XI deficiency, also known as Haemophilia C, is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with mild to moderate bleeding symptoms.
  • The bleeding tendency is generally less severe than that seen in Haemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) or Haemophilia B (Factor IX deficiency).
  • Interestingly, the severity of bleeding does not correlate with the factor XI level, unlike other coagulation factor deficiencies.
  • Factor XI helps in thrombin generation and activates the thrombin-activatable fibrinolysis inhibitor.
  • Therefore, bleeding is often seen in areas of high fibrinolytic activity, such as the oral cavity, nasopharynx, or urinary tract.
  • Bleeding may occur after trauma or surgery, especially dental procedures.

Explanation of other options:

Factor V (Option A): Deficiency of factor V is called parahemophilia, also autosomal recessive. It leads to moderate bleeding, but it is not termed Haemophilia C.

Factor VIII (Option B): Deficiency of factor VIII causes Haemophilia A, the most common form of haemophilia, inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. It presents with joint bleeds (hemarthrosis) and deep tissue bleeding.

Factor IX (Option C): Factor IX deficiency causes Haemophilia B (Christmas disease), also X-linked recessive, and has a similar presentation to Haemophilia A.

choices.text: It is an X-linked recessive disorder
It is caused by a deficiency of clotting factor VIII
It presents as a frequent mucosal bleed

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Haemophilia A is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Haemophilia A is a clotting factor deficiency, not a platelet disorder, and therefore it does not typically present with mucosal bleeds.
  • Instead, it manifests as deep tissue bleeding, such as hemarthrosis, muscle bleeds, and intracranial haemorrhage.

Hemophilia A

  • Caused by a deficiency of Factor VIII. (Option B)
  • Inherited as an X-linked recessive (Option A)
  • Affects mostly males; females are typically carriers. (Option D)
  • Presents with deep tissue bleeds such as joint bleeds (hemarthroses) and muscle hematomas.

Haemophilia B (Christmas Disease)

  • Caused by a deficiency of Factor IX.
  • Inheritance and clinical features are similar to Haemophilia A.
  • Managed with recombinant Factor IX

Hemophilia C

  • Caused by a deficiency of Factor XI.
  • Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Bleeding is usually mild, more prominent after surgery or trauma.
  • More common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is suffering from progressive anaemia. On examination, malar prominence and hepatosplenomegaly were seen. Peripheral smear is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child presents with anaemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and malar prominence, which are classical signs of a chronic hemolytic anaemia.
  • The peripheral smear shows target cells, which are red blood cells with a central bull's-eye appearance due to excess cell membrane relative to cell volume.
  • This morphological change is characteristically seen in thalassemia due to defective globin chain synthesis, which alters RBC membrane structure.
  • The presence of target cells along with clinical features like progressive anaemia and hemolytic facies (malar prominence) strongly suggests the diagnosis of thalassemia.

Explanation of other options:

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): Typically presents with microcytic hypochromic anaemia, but target cells are not prominent. Peripheral smear usually shows anisopoikilocytosis and pencil cells. Hepatosplenomegaly and malar prominence are not typical.

Sideroblastic anaemia (Option B): Usually features ring sideroblasts seen on bone marrow Prussian blue stain, not peripheral target cells. It is more commonly associated with mitochondrial defects or secondary causes (e.g., alcohol, drugs).

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option C): Characterised by macrocytic RBCs, hypersegmented neutrophils, and often due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Target cells are not a feature. Clinical features may include glossitis or neuropathy, not hemolytic facies.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Haemoglobin - 6.3 g/dL was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. A peripheral smear is done, which is shown. The last transfusion was given at 9 months. What is an investigation for definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child has a clinical history of transfusion dependence, and the peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis with target cells, suggesting thalassemia.
  • HPLC and haemoglobin electrophoresis are initial investigations for thalassemia. However, due to repeated transfusions, results may be inaccurate due to mixed red cell populations.
  • Therefore, globin gene sequencing is the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis and to determine the specific thalassemia variant (α or β type).

Explanation of other options:

HPLC (Option A): Commonly used as a screening tool, but may yield inconclusive results in recently transfused patients due to the presence of donor haemoglobin.

Ferritin (Option C): Helpful in assessing iron overload, but not diagnostic for thalassemia.

Bone marrow aspiration (Option D): May show erythroid hyperplasia in thalassemia, but is invasive and not required for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought in with episodes of icterus and pallor. What is the probable diagnosis, and what was the investigation done for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes, small, densely staining RBCs lacking central pallor, which are classic for Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS).
  • Children with HS often present with intermittent jaundice, pallor, and splenomegaly due to extravascular hemolysis.
  • The Osmotic Fragility Test is the initial diagnostic investigation, which demonstrates increased RBC fragility in hypotonic solutions due to membrane defects.

Explanation of other options:

Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, direct Coombs (Option A): Direct Coombs test is positive in autoimmune hemolysis, but AIHA usually shows spherocytes plus reticulocytosis and hemolysis signs post-infection or drug exposure, without a consistent chronic pattern.

Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, indirect Coombs (Option B): Indirect Coombs detects circulating antibodies in serum (e.g., in hemolytic disease of the newborn), not useful in HS.

Hereditary elliptocytosis, Coombs test (Option D): Elliptocytosis presents with elliptical-shaped RBCs, not spherocytes. Coombs' test is not relevant here.

questions.text: A 12-year-old with a history of recurrent infection and bleeding gums. On investigations, the patient had pancytopenia, and the peripheral smear showed macrocytes. Bone marrow biopsy showed no megakaryocytes and was filled with fat globules. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aplastic anaemia is characterised by peripheral pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) along with a hypocellular or fatty bone marrow. In this patient:

  • History of recurrent infections and gum bleeding- suggest neutropenia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Pancytopenia on smear and macrocytes are common in aplastic anaemia.
  • Fatty marrow with absent megakaryocytes confirms aplastic anaemia.

Explanation of other options:

Myelodysplasia (Option A): Also causes pancytopenia but is typically associated with dysplastic changes in cells and a hypercellular marrow, not fatty infiltration. More common in adults.

ITP (Option C): Characterised by isolated thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow is otherwise normal or may show increased megakaryocytes. Pancytopenia rules it out.

PNH (Option D): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria can present with pancytopenia, but the bone marrow is normocellular or hypercellular, not fatty. Also presents with hemolysis and thrombosis, not seen here.
